hotspots.hotspot:
New Deal

The New Deal was a series of economic programs implemented between 1933 and 1936. These included the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC), which provided jobs such as planting trees and fighting fires. The Works Progress Administration (WPA) hired workers and artists to build and beautify highways, bridges, parks, and public buildings. Social Security—a government pension program for the elderly, disabled, and others—was also established.

Great Society

The Great Society was a set of domestic reform programs promoted by President Lyndon B. Johnson. The main goals of the Great Society were to eliminate poverty and to end racial injustice. The program included greater federal support for education and elderly healthcare, as well as reform of the voting process to help protect minority rights.

Affordable Care Act

In 2010, Congress passed legislation that reformed health insurance coverage and expanded healthcare to some 30 million uninsured Americans.

hotspots.hotspot:
Contract with America

The Contract with America was a document signed in 1994 by Republican Party members in Congress led by Newt Gingrich. The Contract with America detailed the legislative actions the Republicans promised to take if they became the majority party in the U.S. House of Representatives.

content.header: The President, Congress, and Foreign Policy

hotspots.hotspot:
The President and Foreign Policy

  • Directs U.S. foreign policy
  • Serves as commander in chief
  • Appoints ambassadors
  • Makes treaties
  • Works with executive departments and other agencies on diplomacy and military activities

Congress and Foreign Policy

  • Holds the power to declare war
  • Appropriates money
  • Passes joint resolutions
  • Senate ratifies treaties and confirms diplomatic appointments

hotspots.hotspot: Most interest groups try to influence government policy by lobbying, or making direct contact with lawmakers or other government leaders. Lobbyists provide Congress with facts and data about the policies they want implemented. They also provide information through congressional testimony and might help draft bills.

Interest groups use television, the Internet, radio, magazine, and newspaper advertising to create public support for their causes. They also may resort to court action or seek a constitutional amendment to achieve their goals.
Interest groups set up political action committees (or PACs) to collect money and provide financial support for political candidates. They use their money to directly influence election outcomes.
